section1.p: Most languages have three sets of quantifiers:

ul.li: other quantifiers such as many or few, and

section1.p: Each type will be considered in turn.

section2.p: Quantifiers meaning all seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first (or last) in a nominal phrase, in a position distinct from the other quantifiers, but in the same place as words like only and just. These words modify the whole nominal phrase, as in all five children, only Sue's three children and just this many children.
uses the following to express these notions:
In , these are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase.
In , these are expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase, as shown in:

These words occur before after on either side (but not both sides) of before or on both sides of after or on both sides of on both sides of the rest of the nominal phrase. All of these words can occur on either side of the nominal phrase. There are restrictions as to which of these words can occur on each side of the nominal phrase.

Other quantifiers, like many, much, and few, come in a different position in the nominal phrase. In English, this is after an article, demonstrative or possessor and before an adjective and noun, as in John's many black dogs.. Further, these quantifiers can be modified by degree words such as very and so, as in very many dogs or so much waste.
has the following quantifiers of this type:
does not have any degree words which modify the quantifiers.
has degree words which can modify the quantifiers, as shown in:

These degree words occur before after on either side (but not both sides) of before or on both sides of after or on both sides of on both sides of the quantifier. All of the degree words can occur on either side of the quantifier. There are restrictions as to which of these degree words can occur on each side of the quantifier.

Now consider numbers. They cannot be modified by the degree words like the quantifiers can, though they occur in the same position. Cardinal numbers can, however, be modified by ordinal numbers and by next and last, as in the first twenty boys or the next one hundred years. Ordinal numbers and next and last can also modify nouns directly, as in the third girl and the last boy. Since these modifiers (including ordinal numbers) also act as regular adjectives in modifying nouns directly, they act syntactically like adjectives.

section3.p: The basic forms for the cardinal numbers are given in the following chart:

Larger cardinal numbers can be compounds which may be written as separate words, such as one hundred thirty three, four thousand and three or six thousand one hundred and thirty three. Examples of compound numbers in include:
Based on the position of the unit number and any conjunctions, cardinal numbers in are left- right- headed.

Ordinal numbers in are formed by adding an affix to the cardinal number. are all independent syntactic words, distinct from the cardinal numbers. may be formed by adding an affix to the cardinal number, but some forms are independent syntactic words. The first ten ordinal numbers are:

When the ordinal numbers modify a cardinal number, as in the first twenty boys, they occur before after on either side (but not both sides) of before or on both sides of after or on both sides of on both sides of the cardinal number. All of the ordinal numbers can occur on either side of the cardinal number. There are restrictions as to which of the ordinal numbers can occur on each side of the cardinal number.
